questions.text: The earliest radiological sign in Pott’s disease is:
questions.correct_answer: C. Narrowing of intervertebral disc space
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Narrowing of intervertebral disc space

options.label: A

options.label: C

questions.correct_answer: A. It begins just behind the anterior horn of lateral meniscus on tibia

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common muscle to be congenitally absent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pectoralis major

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Semimembranosus: The semimembranosus is one of the hamstring muscles located in the posterior thigh. Congenital absence of the semimembranosus is relatively uncommon, and specific conditions associated with the absence of this muscle are less frequently reported.
  • • Option B.
  • • Semimembranosus:
  • • Option C. Teres Minor : The teres minor is a small muscle in the rotator cuff of the shoulder. Congenital absence of the teres minor is rare and might be associated with other shoulder or rotator cuff abnormalities.
  • • Option C. Teres Minor :
  • • Option D. Gluteus maximus : The gluteus maximus is the largest muscle in the buttocks and is involved in hip extension. Congenital absence of the gluteus maximus is extremely rare, and there are limited reports of such cases.
  • • Option D. Gluteus maximus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While congenital absence of certain muscles is associated with specific conditions (e.g., Poland syndrome for pectoralis major), the absence of muscles like semimembranosus, teres minor, or gluteus maximus is uncommon and may be part of rare congenital anomalies. The most common muscle to be congenitally absent among the options provided is the pectoralis major.
  • ➤ While congenital absence of certain muscles is associated with specific conditions (e.g., Poland syndrome for pectoralis major), the absence of muscles like semimembranosus, teres minor, or gluteus maximus is uncommon and may be part of rare congenital anomalies.
  • ➤ The most common muscle to be congenitally absent among the options provided is the pectoralis major.

questions.text: Patellar clunk syndrome is a known complication of which surgery?

options.label: D
options.text: Bicondylar plating of proximal tibia fracture

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Total knee replacement

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Corrective osteotomy for genu valgum: Corrective osteotomy for genu valgum involves surgically realigning the bones to correct a deformity where the knee is deviated outward. Patellar clunk syndrome is not typically associated with this type of corrective osteotomy.
  • • Option A. Corrective osteotomy for genu valgum:
  • • Option C. Medial patellofemoral ligament reconstruction : Medial patellofemoral ligament (MPFL) reconstruction is a surgical procedure to stabilize the patella and prevent dislocation. While complications can occur, patellar clunk syndrome is not a common issue following MPFL reconstruction.
  • • Option C.
  • • Medial patellofemoral ligament reconstruction
  • • :
  • • Option D. Bicondylar plating of proximal tibia fracture : Bicondylar plating of a proximal tibia fracture involves the use of a plate and screws to stabilize a fracture in the upper part of the tibia. Patellar clunk syndrome is not commonly associated with this type of fracture fixation.
  • • Option D.
  • • Bicondylar plating of proximal tibia fracture
  • • :

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patellar clunk syndrome is a known complication of Total Knee replacement surgery.
  • ➤ Patellar clunk syndrome is a known complication of Total Knee replacement surgery.

questions.text: All of the following are the causes of sudden increase in pain in osteochondroma, except :
Most vascular zone of the bone is:
All are seen in anterior shoulder dislocation except:
Extensor Carpi Radialis Longus is:

options.label: A
options.text: Extensor and ulnar deviator of the wrist

options.label: B
options.text: Extensor and radial deviator of the wrist

options.label: C
options.text: Injured in posterior interosseous nerve injury

questions.correct_answer: B. Extensor and radial deviator of the wrist
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Extensor and radial deviator of the wrist

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Extensor and ulnar deviator of the wrist : The extensor carpi radialis longus is the prime extensor of the wrist, but it is not the ulnar deviator. The ulnar deviation is performed by the extensor carpi ulnaris muscle, while the extensor carpi radialis longus muscle performs the radial deviation of the wrist.
  • • Option A. Extensor and ulnar deviator of the wrist
  • • Option C. Injured in posterior interosseous nerve injury : Due to PIN injury, the ulnar wrist extensors and the MCP joint extensors are compromised. The most commonly affected muscle is extensor carpi ulnaris.
  • • Option C. Injured in posterior interosseous nerve injury
  • • Option D. Weak extensor of wrist : The extensor carpi ulnaris is generally considered as the weak extensor of the wrist.
  • • Option D. Weak extensor of wrist
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Extensor carpi radialis longus is the prime extensor and radial deviator of the wrist.
  • • Extensor carpi radialis longus is the prime extensor and radial deviator of the wrist.

On examination: Distal pulses – Absent Passive stretching of right leg – Pain increases Opening the plaster – Right leg appears edematous and numerous blisters are seen What would be the most appropriate management for the given condition?

options.text: Opening of the plaster is sufficient

questions.text: A young patient with RTA sustained an open fracture of femur which was operated on and stabilized as shown below. Identify the fixator.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rail fixator

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. K-nail: Femoral shaft fractures are one of the commonest high energy fractures, and intramedullary nailing is the gold standard management of these fractures. Intramedullary fixation is considered superior to plate fixation because of lower rates of infection, early weight-bearing, and lesser chances of non-union. Unlocked Kuntscher nail (K-nail) should only be used for isthmic femoral shaft fractures. The main drawback of K-nail for use in other types of femoral shaft fracture was lack of rotational stability. Nowadays, interlocking intramedullary nail is used for almost all types of femoral shaft fractures because of better rotational stability.
  • • Option A. K-nail:
  • • Option C. Ilizarov fixator: Ilizarov fixator is an effective treatment modality of open comminuted femur fractures with high union rate, adequate alignment and satisfactory functional outcomes. Ilizarov fixator works on the principles of distraction osteogenesis that is an osteotomy is carried out and distracted at the rate of 1 mm per day causing distraction at the callus and subsequently lengthening can be done. It can be used for correction of deformities like malunion, shortening, shortening with discharging sinus, gap non-union and also for CTEV. For treating bone gap when Ilizarov ring fixator is used, it achieves union, eradicates infection, corrects deformities, reestablishes limb length and at the same time maintains function.
  • • Option C. Ilizarov fixator:
  • • Ilizarov fixator
  • • distraction osteogenesis
  • • distracted at the rate of 1 mm per day
  • • Option D. Proximal femoral nail: The proximal femoral nail (PFN) is an osteosynthetic implant is used to treat proximal femoral fractures in the trochanter area with a closed intramedullary fixation method. It consists of a funnel-shaped intramedullary nail with slight bending to reflect proximal femoral diaphyseal trochanteric morphology. It has two proximal openings, a larger one distally for a large femoral neck lag screw and a smaller one immediately above for a smaller anti-rotation screw/pin. There are small holes at the distal end of the nail for locking screws. It can be combined with a wire cerclage with an open reduction for additional stability in complicated subtrochanteric fractures.
  • • Option D. Proximal femoral nail:
  • • proximal femoral nail (PFN)
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The fixator shown in the image in the question is a Rail Fixator, used to treat open fractures to fill the bone gap.

questions.text: Steps of surgery of DDH in a child < 2 years: Capsulotomy Femoral osteotomy Identification of true acetabulum using round ligament Placing the head back into acetabulum
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) a→

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • DEVELOPMENTAL DYSPLASIA OF HIP (DDH)
  • • DEVELOPMENTAL DYSPLASIA OF HIP (DDH)
  • • This is a spontaneous dislocation of the hip occurring before, during or shortly after birth. DDH is failure of maintenance of femoral head due to malfor- mations of acetabulum or femur. More common in girls usually seen on left side. Etiology and Pathogenesis: Hereditary predisposition Hormonal factors: High levels of maternal estrogen, progesterone & relaxin in the last few weeks of pregnancy may aggravate ligamentous laxity in the infant. Breech malposition favors dislocation. It is associated with higher incidence of plagiocephaly and congenital torticollis. Clinical diagnosis:
  • • This is a spontaneous dislocation of the hip occurring before, during or shortly after birth.
  • • DDH is failure of maintenance of femoral head due to malfor- mations of acetabulum or femur.
  • • More common in girls usually seen on left side.
  • • Etiology and Pathogenesis: Hereditary predisposition Hormonal factors: High levels of maternal estrogen, progesterone & relaxin in the last few weeks of pregnancy may aggravate ligamentous laxity in the infant. Breech malposition favors dislocation. It is associated with higher incidence of plagiocephaly and congenital torticollis.
  • • Etiology and Pathogenesis:
  • • Hereditary predisposition Hormonal factors: High levels of maternal estrogen, progesterone & relaxin in the last few weeks of pregnancy may aggravate ligamentous laxity in the infant. Breech malposition favors dislocation. It is associated with higher incidence of plagiocephaly and congenital torticollis.
  • • Hereditary predisposition
  • • Hormonal factors: High levels of maternal estrogen, progesterone & relaxin in the last few weeks of pregnancy may aggravate ligamentous laxity in the infant.
  • • Hormonal factors:
  • • Breech malposition favors dislocation.
  • • It is associated with higher incidence of plagiocephaly and congenital torticollis.
  • • Clinical diagnosis:
  • • Clinical diagnosis:
  • • 1. Barlow’s test:
  • • 1. Barlow’s test:
  • • The examiner grasps the upper part of each thigh, with his fingers behind on the greater trochanter and thumb in front. An attempt is made to lever the femoral head in and out of the acetabulum during abduction and adduction . If femoral head is normally in reduced position but can be made to slip out of the socket & back in again, hip is classed as ‘dislocatable’ (i.e. unstable).
  • • The examiner grasps the upper part of each thigh, with his fingers behind on the greater trochanter and thumb in front.
  • • An attempt is made to lever the femoral head in and out of the acetabulum during abduction and adduction .
  • • femoral head in and out of the acetabulum during abduction and adduction
  • • If femoral head is normally in reduced position but can be made to slip out of the socket & back in again, hip is classed as ‘dislocatable’ (i.e. unstable).
  • • ‘dislocatable’
  • • 2. Ortolani test:
  • • 2. Ortolani test:
  • • This test is similar to the second part of Barlow’s test . The hips and knees are held in a flexed position and gradually abducted. A ‘click of entrance’ will be felt as the femoral head slips into the acetabulum from the position of dislocation.
  • • This test is similar to the second part of Barlow’s test .
  • • similar to the second part of Barlow’s test
  • • The hips and knees are held in a flexed position and gradually abducted.
  • • A ‘click of entrance’ will be felt as the femoral head slips into the acetabulum from the position of dislocation.
  • • ‘click of entrance’
  • • 3. Galeazzi’s sign:
  • • 3. Galeazzi’s sign:
  • • The level of the knees is compared in a child lying with hip flexed to 70° and knees flexed. There is a lowering of the knee on the affected side
  • • The level of the knees is compared in a child lying with hip flexed to 70° and knees flexed.
  • • There is a lowering of the knee on the affected side
  • • 4. Vascular sign of Narath:
  • • 4. Vascular sign of Narath:
  • • The femoral artery pulse is palpated against the femoral head. If very readily palpated: Possible unreduced anterior hip dislocation. If palpated with great difficulty, it implies femoral head displaced from the hip joint due to hip dislocation, most commonly posterior hip dislocation .
  • • The femoral artery pulse is palpated against the femoral head.
  • • If very readily palpated: Possible unreduced anterior hip dislocation.
  • • If very readily palpated:
  • • If palpated with great difficulty, it implies femoral head displaced from the hip joint due to hip dislocation, most commonly posterior hip dislocation .
  • • If palpated with great difficulty,
  • • most commonly posterior hip dislocation
  • • Imaging:
  • • Imaging:
  • • Imaging:
  • • Ultrasonography: It is widely used as a screening test for DDH. It has the advantage of demonstrating acetabulum the non-ossified femoral head. Plain Radiograph: Delayed appearance of the ossification centre of the head of the femur. Retarded development of the ossification centre of the head of the femur. Sloping acetabulum Lateral and upward displacement of the ossification centre of the femoral head. A break in Shenton’s line Treatment: Surgical approach: The aim in DDH is to place the head of femur in acetabulum. Open the joint, identify the acetabulum, cut and rotate the femur and place the head in acetabulum. Surgical procedure: Percutaneous adductor tenotomy is performed in all patients prior to open reduction. The hip joint is approached superficially between sartorius and tensor fascia lata. The sartorius is detached from anterior superior iliac spine to improve exposure. The anteromedial capsule is incised to remove the obstacle to reduction. The femoral head is identified and ligamentum teres is cut and traced to the acetabulum. The psoas tendon is identified and tenotomy is done to improve access to the acetabulum. The acetabular labrum is identified and care is taken to keep it intact and undamaged. The transverse acetabular ligament is identified and incised to remove the inferior obstacle to reduction. The acetabulum is cleared of fibrocartilaginous tissue and femoral head is reduced into the acetabulum.
  • • Ultrasonography: It is widely used as a screening test for DDH. It has the advantage of demonstrating acetabulum the non-ossified femoral head.
  • • Ultrasonography:
  • • Plain Radiograph: Delayed appearance of the ossification centre of the head of the femur. Retarded development of the ossification centre of the head of the femur. Sloping acetabulum Lateral and upward displacement of the ossification centre of the femoral head. A break in Shenton’s line

  • • Retarded development of the ossification centre of the head of the femur.
  • • Sloping acetabulum
  • • Lateral and upward displacement of the ossification centre of the femoral head.
  • • A break in Shenton’s line

The acetabulum is cleared of fibrocartilaginous tissue and femoral head is reduced into the acetabulum.

Evaluate the following statements with respect to intertrochanteric fracture: More common in males than females. 1 year mortality rate is 20-30%. It is more commonly associated with nonunion than fracture neck of femur. 1 year mortality can be reduced by operating within 48 hours.

options.label: D
options.text: a, b, c, d are correct

questions.correct_answer: C. b and d are correct
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) b and d are correct.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • INTERTROCHANTERIC FRACTURE FEMUR
  • • INTERTROCHANTERIC FRACTURE FEMUR
  • • Intertrochanteric fractures are extracapsular fractures of the proximal femur that occur between the greater and lesser trochanter. This metaphyseal region has a more abundant blood supply, contributing to a higher union rate and less osteonecrosis compared to femoral neck fractures. Etiology: These fractures occur both in the elderly and the young, but they are more common in the elderly population with osteoporosis due to a low energy mechanism. The female to male ration is between 2:1 and 8:1. In the younger population, these fractures typically result from a high-energy mechanism. These patients present with a short and externally rotated limb. Treatment:
  • • Intertrochanteric fractures are extracapsular fractures of the proximal femur that occur between the greater and lesser trochanter.
  • • This metaphyseal region has a more abundant blood supply, contributing to a higher union rate and less osteonecrosis compared to femoral neck fractures.
  • • Etiology: These fractures occur both in the elderly and the young, but they are more common in the elderly population with osteoporosis due to a low energy mechanism. The female to male ration is between 2:1 and 8:1. In the younger population, these fractures typically result from a high-energy mechanism.
  • • Etiology:
  • • These fractures occur both in the elderly and the young, but they are more common in the elderly population with osteoporosis due to a low energy mechanism. The female to male ration is between 2:1 and 8:1. In the younger population, these fractures typically result from a high-energy mechanism.
  • • These fractures occur both in the elderly and the young, but they are more common in the elderly population with osteoporosis due to a low energy mechanism.
  • • The female to male ration is between 2:1 and 8:1.
  • • In the younger population, these fractures typically result from a high-energy mechanism.
  • • These patients present with a short and externally rotated limb.
  • • Treatment:
  • • Treatment:
  • • Treatment of choice: Dynamic Hip Screw (Undisplaced fracture). Displaced fracture: Proximal femoral nail (Cephalomedullary nail). Latest literature claims better results with Proximal Femoral Nail (PFN). Most common complication is malunion. 1 year mortality rate is 20-30%. 1 year mortality can be reduced by operating within 48 hours.
  • • Treatment of choice: Dynamic Hip Screw (Undisplaced fracture).
  • • Treatment of choice:
  • • Displaced fracture: Proximal femoral nail (Cephalomedullary nail).
  • • Displaced fracture:
  • • Latest literature claims better results with Proximal Femoral Nail (PFN).
  • • Most common complication is malunion.
  • • 1 year mortality rate is 20-30%.
  • • 1 year mortality can be reduced by operating within 48 hours.
  • • INTERTROCHANTERIC FRACTURE VS NECK OF FEMUR FRACTURE
  • • INTERTROCHANTERIC FRACTURE VS NECK OF FEMUR FRACTURE
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Intertrochanteric fracture is more common in females than males. Most common complication is malunion. 1 year mortality rate is 20-30%. 1 year mortality can be reduced by operating within 48 hours.
